channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Unverified Data Points to Rapid Loss of Control Aboard EgyptAir Jet
item.media:description: Osman Abu Laban, center, who lost four relatives in the EgyptAir plane crash, after prayers for the dead at a mosque in Cairo on Friday.
item.description: Sensor data made public by a respected aviation journal, which could not be independently confirmed, indicates rapid and escalating failures in the plane’s flight control system.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and MARC SANTORA

item.title: As Hamas Tunnels Back Into Israel, Gazans Fear They’ll Be Caught in the Crossfire
item.media:description: Salma Najjar outside a makeshift shelter on the rubble of her home in Khuzaa in the Gaza Strip in October 2014, after the war between Israel and Hamas. Hamas is rebuilding tunnels from Gaza into Israel, and residents are worried about Israeli bombs dropping on their homes once again.
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.description: Hamas is busy tunneling its way back toward Israel, and Palestinians who live over the passageways fear they will bear the cost of the eventual Israeli response.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and MAJD AL WAHEIDI

item.title: Iraqi Protesters Clash With Troops in Baghdad’s Green Zone
item.description: A short-lived but telling show of unrest as security forces fire tear gas to remove demonstrators who had stormed the prime minister’s office.
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY and FALIH HASSAN

item.title: Moshe Yaalon, Israeli Defense Minister, Resigns
item.description: The abrupt move came as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu publicly conducted negotiations with a far-right party to join his government.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ and IRIT PAZNER GARSHOWITZ

item.title: Pray for Shade: Heat Wave Sets a Record in India
item.media:description: Golu, a 10-year-old boy living on the streets of New Delhi, played in a decorative pool in the gardens surrounding the India Gate monument on Friday.
item.description: May is typically the hottest month in much of India, but 123.8 degrees is a record — and it is amplified by a drought across much of the country.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Obama’s Vietnam Trip Follows Controlled Parliamentary Elections
item.media:description: An election poster in Hanoi, Vietnam, last month. By the time President Obama arrives Sunday night, all-day voting in parliamentary races will have just finished.
item.description: President Obama arrives as the voting will have finished, and the names not allowed to appear on the ballots tell more of a story than that of those allowed to compete.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Abe Voices Outrage After Former U.S. Marine Is Arrested in Okinawa Killing
item.media:description: “I am extremely upset. I have no words,” Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said in Tokyo on Friday in response to the arrest.
item.description: Crimes committed by Americans have long been a source of friction, and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe demanded that the United States take preventive action.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Susana Malcorra of Argentina Becomes Candidate for U.N. Secretary General
item.media:description: Susana Malcorra had served as chief of staff to Secretary General Ban Ki-moon before becoming Argentina’s foreign minister.
item.description: Ms. Malcorra, the foreign minister of Argentina, becomes the fifth woman among 10 candidates to succeed Secretary General Ban Ki-moon.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Mexico OKs Extradition of Drug Lord 'El Chapo' Guzman to US
item.description: Mexico's Foreign Relations Department ruled Friday that the extradition of convicted drug lord Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman to the United States can go forward.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: A Girl Rescued in Nigeria Was Not Taken in Chibok Kidnapping, Group Says
item.description: One of the two girls rescued from Boko Haram this week was abducted from her hometown, Madagali, and was not taken in a mass kidnapping in Chibok in 2014, an advocacy group said.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STEIN

item.title: Ban on Catalan Flag at Spanish Soccer Final Is Overturned
item.description: The authorities in Madrid had tried to prohibit the Estelada, a Catalan flag that has become a symbol of a pro-independence movement.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Turkish Parliament Approves Stripping Lawmakers of Their Immunity
item.media:description: Members of the Kurdish People’s Democratic Party, left, reacted as deputies with the governing party voted to lawmakers’ immunity from prosecution in Ankara, Turkey, on Friday.
item.description: Turkey’s ruling party pushed through the amendment to the Constitution on Friday, a move that is likely to lead to the ouster of Kurdish deputies.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: How Do You Move a City? Ask Kiruna, Sweden
item.media:description: Kiruna, Sweden, in 2012. It is home to about 18,000 people.
item.description: It has nothing to do with climate change: The Arctic Circle city will be moved about two miles east so it doesn’t collapse into the mine underneath.
item.dc:creator: JONAH BROMWICH

item.title: Case Against Photographer Over Paris Massacre Picture Is Dismissed
item.media:description: Maya Vidon-White, at home in Paris last month, was prosecuted after her photograph of a man killed in the November terrorist attacks was published in a French magazine.
item.media:credit: Capucine Granier-Deferre for The New York Times
item.description: A judge sided with a photographer who said she had committed no crime in taking a graphic picture of a man killed in the November terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Paris Bombing Suspect Refuses to Cooperate With Investigation
item.media:description: French soldiers in the convoy that transported Salah Abdeslam, a suspect in the November terrorist attacks in Paris, to the Palais de Justice on Friday.
item.description: Salah Abdeslam thinks he is being treated differently than other inmates, his lawyer says, and has so far declined to answer questions from investigators.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Doctor Killed in Bangladeshi Machete Attack
item.description: Sanaur Rahman was on a motorcycle driven by a friend when three men on another motorcycle struck him in the head, killing him instantly.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Tycoon on the Run Hopes Russia’s Reach Stops at the French Riviera’s Edge
item.media:description: Sergei Pugachev, a businessman and former politician, fled Russia for Britain. Then, fearing for his life there, he moved to Nice, France.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Sergei Pugachev, who just a few years ago ranked as one of Russia’s richest, best connected and most secretive magnates, said he “felt the noose tightening.”
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Celebrities, in Open Letter, Urge Britons to Stay in E.U.
item.media:description: A pro-European Union event in Witney, England, this month. Many cross-border collaborations to fund films and TV programs are made easier by membership in the single market of the bloc, and it is easier for British artists to work in Europe and vice versa.
item.description: In the letter, published in The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian, the signers argued that “our global creative success would be severely weakened by walking away.”
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: ‘Brexit,’ a Feel-Good Vote That Could Sink Britain’s Economy
item.media:description: The Brandauer factory was started 154 years ago as a maker of nibs for pens. These days, it makes components that are used in a range of everyday items, including cars and teakettles.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: In their desire to leave the E.U., many Britons have found an outlet for fears about immigration and terrorism. But the cost of an exit would be high.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: Taiwan President Takes Cautious Line on China at Inauguration
item.media:description: Guests listened as President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan gave her inauguration speech in Taipei on Friday.
item.description: President Tsai Ing-wen, whose party has traditionally supported the island’s independence, called on both governments to “set aside the baggage of history.”
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Tsai Ing-wen Sworn In as Taiwan’s President, as China Watches Closely
item.media:description: Taiwan’s new president, Tsai Ing-wen, arrived with her vice president, Chen Chien-jen, second from right, for her inauguration ceremony in Taipei on Friday.
item.description: The island’s first female leader takes power with the economy in a slump and the region watching her first moves with a juggernaut neighbor.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Marlene Marder, Guitarist for Influential Post-Punk Band Liliput, Dies at 61
item.media:description: Marlene Marder, left, on the cover of a record by Liliput, a Swiss female post-punk band active from 1978 to 1983.
item.description: Ms. Marder brought a distinctive sound to the group, a four-woman Swiss band whose admirers included Kurt Cobain.
item.dc:creator: JON PARELES

item.title: EgyptAir Crash Blindsides a Nation That Thought It Was Recovering
item.media:description: A relative of a passenger on EgyptAir Flight 804 inside a bus at the airport in Cairo on Thursday.
item.description: For years, Egypt has been hit with crisis after crisis, devastating its economic lifeblood, tourism. But recently, there had been signs of a turnaround.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Killing of Bulls Is Banned at Toro de la Vega Festival in Spain
item.description: The move by the regional government of Castile and León comes amid tensions over the annual festival in Tordesillas and other events that animal rights activists say involves cruelty.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Another Chibok Schoolgirl Kidnapped by Boko Haram Is Found, Nigeria Says
item.media:description: President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria, in glasses, met Amina Ali, one of nearly 300 girls kidnapped by Boko Haram in 2014, and her daughter on Thursday, two days after they were found.
item.description: The discovery of Serah Luka on Thursday was announced hours after Amina Ali, another kidnapping victim who was found Tuesday, met with President Muhammadu Buhari in the capital.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STEIN and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Benigno Aquino Says U.S. Must Act if China Moves on Reef in South China Sea
item.description: The Philippine leader said that if Beijing decided to develop the Scarborough Shoal, the United States would be forced to defend the Philippines or risk losing credibility.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: W.H.O. Calls Yellow Fever in Africa ‘Serious Concern’
item.description: The agency stopped short of declaring a global health emergency, but suggested drastically expanding vaccination programs.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: NATO Invites Montenegro to Join Alliance
item.description: NATO made a formal invitation on Thursday to tiny Montenegro to join the alliance as its 29th member, a move Russia strongly objects to.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Bharatiya Janata Party Rebounds in Indian State Elections
item.media:description: Sarbananda Sonwal, front, the Bharatiya Janata Party’s candidate to lead Assam state, after his party’s victory on Thursday.
item.description: The party, led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, made inroads in the country’s northeast after disappointing results in previous elections.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Despair, Anger and Scant Hope for Relatives of EgyptAir Passengers
item.description: Reports and relatives spoke of a passenger who lost his passport but found it in time to make the flight and of a young man who was flying home after his mother’s death.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Erdogan Loyalist Is Nominated to Be Turkey’s Prime Minister
item.media:description: Commemorating the founder of modern Turkey, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, in Istanbul on Thursday.
item.description: Binali Yildirim is virtually assured of replacing Ahmet Davutoglu, who resigned after clashing with Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Turkey’s increasingly authoritarian president.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: French Parliament Votes to Extend State of Emergency
item.media:description: President François Hollande declared a state of emergency in France on Nov. 14, 2015.
item.description: The extension, the third since the attacks in and around Paris on Nov. 13, will cover two major sporting events this summer, including the Euro 2016 soccer tournament.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: San Antonio de Lourdes Journal: Prosperous Mexican Farms Suck Up Water, Leaving Villages High and Dry
item.media:description: The Rev. Juan Carlos Zesati, center, blessing a recently constructed rainwater cistern in Guanajuato State, central Mexico.
item.media:credit: Janet Jarman for The New York Times
item.description: Scientists warn that as farms bore deeper into the aquifer they are reaching tainted water deposited between 10,000 and 35,000 years ago.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: What in the World: For This Green Smoothie, the First Ingredient Is Frog
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photo by Hintau Aliaksei/Shutterstock
item.description: In Peru and Bolivia, drinks made from the endangered Titicaca water frog are promoted as a cure for many ailments, without scientific support.
item.dc:creator: EVAN GERSHKOVICH

item.title: What in the World: China Offers Airport Security for Women, and Their Makeup
item.description: “Female Only” security lines are at four airports, in part so women are not frisked by men, but also because cosmetics require greater scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: What in the World: A British Town Weighs Its Officials’ Merits, With Scales
item.media:credit: Illustration by Cari Vander Yacht; Photos by Claudio Divizia/Shutterstock
item.description: Tradition equates getting fat in office with fiscal imprudence or worse, so once a year, politicians have to mount the scales in public.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Opinion: Among the Healers
item.media:description: Adalberto Salcedo, a shaman known as Delfin, near Guadalajara, Mexico.
item.media:credit: Daniel Borris for The New York Times
item.description: Therapy, medication and yoga couldn’t cure my anxiety. Maybe Rafael could.
item.dc:creator: DIANA SPECHLER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Russia Is Trying to Wipe Out Crimea’s Tatars
item.description: More than two years after Putin annexed the peninsula, the world has turned a blind eye.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA M. PASCHYN
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Editorial: French Women Fight Back
item.media:description: Activists demonstrated against sexual harassment of women last week in Paris.
item.description: Current and former government ministers are taking a stand against the sexism of their male colleagues.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Mao and Me: A Beijing Correspondent Reflects
item.media:description: Mao's portrait hangs in many cars in China, a talisman against accidents. This one hangs in the car of Chen Lei, a driver for a Russian bank. Taken in Beijing on May 18. 2016.
item.description: On the 50th anniversary of the Cultural Revolution, Didi Kirsten Tatlow knows she’s not the only person in China who’s dreaming about the Chairman.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
